qas.question: During the Middle Ages, who was no longer expected to stay behind walls away from the common man?
How many orders of mendicant friars came out of the Middle Ages?
Who led the Friars Minor order at this time?
Dominic of Guzman led what order of mendicant friars?
What two groups grew quickly during the Middle Ages?

plausible_answers.text: when religion began to be contemplated in a new way

qas.question: What was not occurring when the Dominican Order came into being in the Middle Ages?
What were Men of God expected to stay behind?
How many orders of mendicant friars did not come out of the Middle Ages?
Who led the Friars Major order at this time?
Who led the Friars Teachers order at this time?

context: The Dominican Order came into being in the Middle Ages at a time <b5_0>when religion began to be contemplated in a new way<b5_0/>. <a0_0>Men of God<a0_0/> were no longer expected to stay behind the <b6_0>walls of a cloister<b6_0/>. Instead, they travelled among the people, taking as their examples the apostles of the primitive Church. Out of this ideal emerged <a1_0><b7_0>two<b7_0/><a1_0/> orders of mendicant friars: one, the Friars Minor, was led by <a2_0><b8_0>Francis of Assisi<b8_0/><a2_0/>; the other, <a3_0>the Friars Preachers<a3_0/>, by <b9_0>Dominic of Guzman<b9_0/>. Like his contemporary, Francis, Dominic saw the need for a new type of organization, and the quick growth of <a4_0>the Dominicans and Franciscans<a4_0/> during their first century of existence confirms that the orders of mendicant friars met a need.
